Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Student support for 2017 Napa Microsystems Workshop. To Be Held in Napa, California, August, 21-23, 2017

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed project seeks financial support to support the conference registration costs of up to 50 student participants of the 2017 Napa Microsystems Workshop, which will be held in Napa, CA on 21-23 August 2017. The meeting is to bring together researchers on the themes of non-reciprocal systems, nonlinear systems, parametric resonance, optomechanics, and microsystems for computing. The central thesis for the workshop is that micro-electro-mechanical sensors and actuators are approaching a saturation point in technology development due to the fundamental assumptions of linear time invariance and reciprocity. A study of non-linear, non-reciprocal, and parametric systems is therefore necessary to overcome currently faced barriers. The cross-pollination of ideas between the above described different physical domains plays a critical role in developing new applications, for example, borrowed concepts from optics and opto-mechanics can stimulate new capabilities in microwave, RF, and acoustic systems. The Workshop will provide opportunities for a diverse group of graduate student researchers to interact with senior members of the research community, broadening their scientific perspective and promoting their career development. It will enhance understanding of the science that underpins the development of micro/nanoscale sensors, actuators, and microsystems and will promote long-term relationships between researchers in diverse fields including bioengineering, chemical engineering, mechanical engineering, electrical engineering and chemistry. The will be Workshop proceedings that will be disseminated among the conference attendees either digitally or as a proceedings book of abstracts

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided student travel support to the 2017 Napa Microsystems Workshop held in Napa, CA on 21-­23 Aug 2017. The research areas of nonlinear and non­reciprocal systems have been recently experiencing an exciting phase of growth and fundamental discovery, as evidenced by demonstrations of novel topological phases, one­way propagating modes, chiral edge states, and classical analogues of quantum electronic phenomena. This workshop brought together communities working in mechanical, microwave, and photonic microsystems to facilitate an intellectual exchange on these recent developments. Such contact additionally stimulates discussion on the limitations and bounds of various configurations and topologies. The cross­pollination of ideas between these different physical domains plays a critical role in developing new applications, for example, borrowed concepts from optics and opto­mechanics can stimulate new capabilities in microwave, RF, and acoustic system. A total of 103 attendees were present at this workshop, including 19 from industry, 6 from the US government, and 78 from academia. Notably, the workshop provided opportunities for a diverse group of graduate student researchers to interact with senior members of the research community, broadening their scientific perspective and promoting their career development. A total of 34 graduate students and postdoctoral scholars received travel support through this grant.
